abstract.t: This document specifies rules for deciding whether a codepoint, considered in isolation, is a candidate for inclusion in an Internationalized Domain Name.
It is part of the specification of IDNA200X.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: RFC 4690 suggests an inclusion based approach for selecting the codepoints from The Unicode Standard that should be included in the list of codepoints that may be used in Internationalized Domain Names.
Specifically, RFC 4690 says the following:

list.t: The IAB has concluded that there is a consensus within the broader community that lists of code points should be specified by the use of an inclusion-based mechanism (i.e., identifying the characters that are permitted), rather than by excluding a small number of characters from the total Unicode set as Stringprep and Nameprep do today. That conclusion should be reviewed by the IETF community and action taken as appropriate.

section.t: This document reviews and classifies the collections of codepoints in the Unicode character set by examining various properties of the codepoints. It then defines an algorithm for determining a derived property value. It specifies a procedure and not a table of codepoints so that the algorithm can be used to determine code point sets independent of the version of Unicode that is in use.

This document is not intended to specify precisely how these property values are to be applied in IDN labels. That information appears in , but it is important to understand that the assignment of a value of this property to a particular character is not sufficient to determine whether it can be used in a given label. In particular, some combinations of allowed codepoints are not advisable for use in IDNs due to rules specific to a script or class of characters. The requirement for such rules is linked to the operations in and especially to the characters designated as requiring contextual rules.
The value of the property is to be interpreted approximately as follows.

list.t: PROTOCOL VALID: Those that are allowed to be used in IDNs. Codepoints with this property value are permitted for general use in IDNs. That a label consists only of codepoints that have this property value does though not imply the label can be used in DNS. See for algorithm for how to make decisions on domain names. The abbreviated term PVALID is used to refer to this value in the rest of this document.

CONTEXTUAL RULE REQUIRED: Some characteristics of the character, such as it being invisible in certain contexts or problematic in others, requires that it not be used in labels unless specific other characters or properties are present. The abbreviated term CONTEXT is used to refer to this value in the rest of this document. There are two subdivisions of CONTEXTUAL RULE REQUIRED, one for Join_controls (called CONTEXTJ) and and for other characters (called CONTEXTO). These are discussed in more detail below and in .
DISALLOWED: Those that should clearly not be included in IDNs. Codepoints with this property value will never be permitted in IDNs.
UNASSIGNED: Those codepoints that are unassigned in the Unicode Standard.

section.t: The (non-normative) table in Appendix A is derived from data in Unicode 5.0, rather than the earlier Unicode 3.2; this in order to take advantage of the expanded character repertoire and better definitions in the newer version. The mechanisms described here allow determination of the value of the property for future versions of Unicode (including characters added after Unicode 5.0). It should be suitable for newer revisions of Unicode, as long as the Unicode properties on which it is based remain stable.
The table is expected to be updated to Unicode 5.1 before publication of this document.

Some codepoints need to be allowed in exceptional circumstances, but should be excluded in all other cases; these rules are also described in other documents. The most notable of these are the ZERO WIDTH JOINER (U+200D) and ZERO WIDTH NON-JOINER (U+200C). Both of them have the derived property value CONTEXTJ. A character with the derived property value CONTEXTJ or CONTEXTO (CONTEXTUAL RULE REQUIRED) is not be used unless an appropriate rule has been established and the context of the character is consistent with that rule. It is invalid to either register a string containing these characters or even to look one up unless such contextual rule is found and satisfied. Please see Appendix A, The Contextual Rules Registry, in for more information.

This document is part of a series that, together, constitute a preliminary proposal for updating the IDNA standards to resolve issues uncovered in recent years, cover a broader range of scripts, and provide for migration to newer versions of Unicode. See for a broader discussion.

section.title: Category definitions Used to Calculate Derived Property Value
Categories Based on Unicode Properties
section.t: The derived property obtains its value based on a two step procedure. First, characters are placed in one or more character categories based on core properties defined by the Unicode Standard. These categories are not mutually exclusive.
In the second step, set operations are used with these categories to determine the values for an IDN-specific property. Those operations are specified in .
In many cases aliases are used in the data in the Unicode Standard. This document uses both the alias and the spelled out terms (for example alias Ll for the General Category Lowercase_Letter).

section.title: Category A - General Categories Allowed

figure.artwork: A: generalCategory(cp) is in {Ll, Lu, Lo, Nd, Lm, Mn, Mc}

section.t: These rules identify characters commonly used in mnemonics and often informally described as "language characters". In general, only codepoints assigned to this category are suitable for use in IDN.

The categories used in this rule are:
Ll - Lowercase_Letter Lu - Uppercase_Letter Lo - Other_Letter Nd - Decimal_Number Lm - Modifier_Letter Mn - Nonspacing_Mark Mc - Spacing_Mark

section.title: Category B - Normalization and Casefolding
section.t: The category is used to group the characters that are not stable under NFKC normalization and casefolding. In general, these codepoints are not suitable for use for IDN.

section.title: Category C - Properties to ignore

figure.artwork: C: property(cp) is in {Default_Ignorable_Code_Point, White_Space, Noncharacter_Code_Point}

section.t: This category is used to group codepoints that are not recommended for use in identifiers. In general, these codepoints are not suitable for use for IDN.

The definition for Default_Ignorable_Code_Point can be found in
DerivedCoreProperties.txt (and erratum of 2007-January-25) and is

figure.artwork: Other_Default_Ignorable_Code_Point + Cf + Cc + Cs + Noncharacter_Code_Point + Variation_Selector - White_Space - FFF9..FFFB (Annotation Characters)

section.title: Category D - Blocks of Characters
section.t: This category rule is used to identifying codepoints that are not useful in mnemonics or that are otherwise impractical for IDN use. In general, these codepoints are not suitable for use for IDN.

section.title: Category E - ASCII LDH
section.t: This category is used in the second step to preserve the traditional "hostname" (LDH) characters ('-', 0-9 and a-z). In general, these codepoints are suitable for use for IDN. Note that the codepoint 0x002D (HYPHEN-MINUS) is also in Category F. It is kept in this category of LDH characters because of clarity although it will never match. This because one can see in , Category F overrides what this category specifies.

section.title: Category F - Exceptions
section.t: This category explicitly lists codepoints for which the category cannot be assigned using only the core property values that exist in the Unicode standard. The values are according to the table below:

figure.artwork: 002D; CONTEXTO # HYPHEN-MINUS 00B7; CONTEXTO # MIDDLE DOT 02B9; CONTEXTO # MODIFIER LETTER PRIME 0375; CONTEXTO # GREEK LOWER NUMERAL SIGN (KERAIA) 0483; CONTEXTO # COMBINING CYRILLIC TILTO 05F3; CONTEXTO # HEBREW PUNCTUATION GERESH 05F4; CONTEXTO # HEBREW PUNCTUATION GERSHAYIM 3005; CONTEXTO # IDEOGRAPHIC ITERATION MARK 3007; PVALID # IDEOGRAPHIC NUMBER ZERO 303B; CONTEXTO # VERTICAL IDEOGRAPHIC ITERATION MARK 30FB; CONTEXTO # KATAKANA MIDDLE DOT

section.t: The characters 02B9, 0375 and 0483 are used in different scripts to indicate that an adjacent letter is being used with a numeric value.

section.title: Category G - Backward compatibility
section.t: This category includes the codepoints that property values in versions of Unicode after 5.0 have changed in such a way that the derived property value would no longer be PVALID or DISALLOWED. As the requirement is that codepoints having either of these derived values MUST NOT have those changed, this category is added, but initially the set of codepoints is empty.

section.title: Category H - Require extended special treatment in Lookup and Resolution
section.t: This category consists of Join Control characters (i.e., they are not in Category A) but are still required in IDN labels under some circumstances.

section.title: Category I - Require special treatment in Lookup and extended special treatment in Resolution
section.t: This category consists of non-language characters (i.e., those not in Category A) but are still required in IDN labels under some circumstances.

section.title: Category J - Unassigned codepoints
section.t: This category consists of codepoints in the Unicode character set that are not (yet) assigned.

section.title: Calculation of the Derived Property
section.t: As described above () and in more detail in the "IDNA Protocol" document, possible values of the IDN property are:

list.t: PVALID
CONTEXTJ
CONTEXTO
DISALLOWED
UNASSIGNED

section.t: The algorithm to calculate the value of the derived property is as follows.

list.t: If the codepoint is in Category F, the value is according to the table in .
If the codepoint is in Category G, the value is according to the table in .
If the codepoint is in Category E, the value is PVALID.
If the codepoint is in Category H, the value is CONTEXTJ.
If the codepoint is in Category I, the value is CONTEXTO.
If the codepoint is in Category B, the value is DISALLOWED.
If the codepoint is in Category C, the value is DISALLOWED.
If the codepoint is in Category D, the value is DISALLOWED.
If the codepoint is in Category J, the value is UNASSIGNED.
If the codepoint is in Category A, the value is PVALID.
If the codepoint is not in Category A, the value is DISALLOWED.

section.title: Codepoints
section.t: The Categories and Rules defined in and apply to all assigned Unicode characters. The table in shows, for illustrative purposes, the consequences of the categories and classification rules, and the resulting property values.
The list of codepoints that can be found in is non-normative. and are normative.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: IANA is to keep a list of the derived property for the versions of Unicode that is released after (and including) version 5.0. The derived property value is to be calculated according to the specifications in sections and and not by copying the non-normative table found in . If needed, IANA should (with the help of an appointed expert) suggest updates of this RFC where Category G is updated, a set that is at release of this document is empty.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security issues associated with this work are discussed in and .

section.title: Contributors
section.t: While the listed editor held the pen, this document represents the joint work and conclusions of an ad hoc design team. In addition to the editor this consisted of, Harald Alvestrand, Tina Dam, Cary Karp, and John Klensin.

section.title: Acknowledgements
section.t: This document would not have been possible to produce without input from many people. The main contribuotrs are (in alphabetical order) Harald Alvestrand, Vint Cerf, Tina Dam, Mark Davis, Mouhammet Diop, Michael Everson, Asmus Freytag, Debbie Garside, Paul Hoffman, Cary Karp, John Klensin, Olaf Kolkman, Lisa Moore, Yngve Pettersen, Erik van der Poel, Hualin Qian, Rick Reed, Michel Suignard and Kenneth Whistler.
